A1.withinarea: Within the area of Physical and Chemical Changes,

T1.wewillselect: we will select the topic Crystal Growth.
T1.belowarevariables: Below are some variables that might affect the amount of crystal growth on a string in water.
T1.enumVar3: The initial amount of crystals on the string
T1.enumProcess1: We will mix a crystal salt or sugar in water so it dissolves.
T1.enumProcess2: We will continue to add the crystals and mix until no more crystals can be dissolved in the water. This is the saturation point.
T1.enumProcess4: Then we will put a string in the water.
T1.enumProcess6: We can measure the weight of the crystal growth after two weeks.
T1.fourcanchange: In this experiment, there are only four things we can change. Any of these might make a difference in the amount of crystal growth on a string in water. These are the four variables you can test in this experiment
T1.enumValue3: The initial amount of crystals on the string
T1.enumValueUtt1a: The water temperature which can be cool.
T1.enumValueUtt1b: Or hot, might make a difference.
T1.enumValueUtt2a: The type of crystal which can be salt
T1.enumValueUtt2b: Or brown sugar, might make a difference.
T1.enumValueUtt3a: The initial amount of crystals on the string which can be some
T1.enumValueUtt3b: Or none, might make a difference.
T1.enumValueUtt4a: And the type of string which can be twine.
T1.enumValueUtt4b: Or yarn. This might also make a difference.

RQ3.rqselected: Does the initial amount of crystals on the string
RQ3.ExpSelected: initial amount of crystals on the string

T1.rqselectedall: affect the weight of the crystal growth on a string in water after two weeks?
T1.rqselectedalls: affects the weight of the crystal growth on a string after two weeks?
T1.DVg: amount of crystal growth on a string in water
T1.DVst: The weight of the crystal growth on the string after two weeks.
T1.DVs: weight of the crystal growth on the string after two weeks.
T1.buttVarName3: The initial amount of crystals on the string

T2.wewillselect: we will select the topic Soda Mint Reactions.
T2.belowarevariables: Below are some variables that might affect the reaction between soda and mints.
T2.enumVar1: The type of sweetener in the soda
T2.enumVar2: The amount of caffeine in the soda
T2.enumVar3: The surface texture of the mint
T2.enumVar4: The amount of carbon dioxide in the soda
T2.enumUtt4: And the amount of carbon dioxide in the soda
T2.enumProcess1: We will put a single mint into a bottle of soda.
T2.enumProcess2: Bubbles forming a soda geyser may come out of the bottle.
T2.enumProcess3: We can measure the height of the soda geyser.
T2.fourcanchange: In this experiment, there are only four things we can change. Any of these might make a difference in the reaction between the soda and mint. These are the four variables you can test in this experiment
T2.enumValue1: The type of sweetener in the soda
T2.enumValue2: The amount of caffeine in the soda
T2.enumValue3: The surface texture of the mint
T2.enumValue4: The amount of carbon dioxide in the soda
T2.enumValueUtt1a: The type of sweetener which can be sugar
T2.enumValueUtt1b: Or aspartame, might make a difference
T2.enumValueUtt2a: The amount of caffeine in the soda which can be some
T2.enumValueUtt2b: Or none, might make a difference
T2.enumValueUtt3a: The surface texture of the mint, which can be smooth
T2.enumValueUtt3b: Or rough, might make a difference
T2.enumValueUtt4a: And the amount of carbon dioxide in the soda which can be high
T2.enumValueUtt4b: Or low. This might also make a difference

RQ1.rqselected: Does the type of sweetener in the soda
RQ1.ExpSelected: type of sweetener in the soda

RQ2.rqselected: Does the amount of caffeine in the soda
RQ2.ExpSelected: amount of caffeine in the soda

RQ3.rqselected: Does the surface texture of the mint

RQ4.rqselected: Does the amount of carbon dioxide in the soda

RQ4.ExpSelected2: The amount of carbon dioxide in the soda

A2.withinarea: Within the area of Heat and Temperature,

T1.wewillselect: we will select the topic Ice Melting Time.
T1.belowarevariables: Below are some variables that might affect the time it takes for an ice cube to melt in water.
T1.enumVar1: The initial temperature of the ice cube
T1.enumVar2: The initial temperature of the water
T1.enumUtt4: And the shape of the glass
T1.enumProcess1: We will place an ice cube in a glass filled with 237 milliliters of water.
T1.enumProcess2: The ice cube will eventually completely melt.
T1.enumProcess3: We can measure the time it takes for the ice cube to melt in water.
T1.fourcanchange: In this experiment, there are only four things we can change. Any of these might make a difference in the time it takes for the ice cube to melt in water. These are the four variables you can test in this experiment
T1.enumValue1: The initial temperature of the ice cube
T1.enumValue2: The initial temperature of the water
T1.enumValueUtt1a: the initial temperature of the ice cube which can be zero degrees Celsius
T1.enumValueUtt1b: Or negative twenty degrees Celsius, might make a difference
T1.enumValueUtt2a: The initial temperature of the water which can be cold
T1.enumValueUtt2b: Or hot, might make a difference
T1.enumValueUtt3a: The pattern on the glass which can be striped
T1.enumValueUtt3b: Or plain, might make a difference
T1.enumValueUtt4a: And the shape of the glass which can be short or
T1.enumValueUtt4b: Tall. This might also make a difference

RQ1.rqselected: Does the initial temperature of the ice cube

T1.rqselectedalls: affects the time it takes for the ice cube to melt in water?

T1.DVst: The time it takes for the ice cube to melt in water
T1.DVs: time it takes for the ice cube to melt in water

T2.wewillselect: we will select the topic Temperature of a Gas.
T2.belowarevariables: Below are some variables that might affect the temperature of gas in a balloon.
T2.enumVar2: The amount of sunlight exposure the balloon gets
T2.enumVar3: The material the balloon is made of
T2.enumVar4: The type of chair the balloon is tied to
T2.enumUtt4: And the type of chair the balloon is tied to
T2.enumMat2: A wireless temperature reader and sensor
T2.enumProcess1: We will pump 5 grams of Helium at 15 degrees Celsius into a balloon.
T2.enumProcess3: Then we will place the balloon outside for 30 minutes.
T2.enumProcess4: The temperature of the outside air is 27 degrees Celsius.
T2.enumProcess5: We can measure the temperature of the gas after 30 minutes.
T2.fourcanchange: In this experiment, there are only four things we can change. Any of these might make a difference in the temperature of gas in the balloon. These are the four variables you can test in this experiment
T2.enumValue2: The amount of sunlight exposure the balloon gets
T2.enumValue3: The material the balloon is made of
T2.enumValue4: The type of chair the balloon is tied to
T2.enumValueUtt1a: The color of the balloon, which can be light
T2.enumValueUtt1b: Or dark, might make a difference
T2.enumValueUtt2a: The amount of sunlight exposure the balloon gets, which can be full sun
T2.enumValueUtt2b: Or shade, might make a difference
T2.enumValueUtt3a: The material the balloon is made of which can be latex
T2.enumValueUtt3b: Or foil, might make a difference
T2.enumValueUtt4a: And the type of chair the balloon is tied to, which can be a wooden chair
T2.enumValueUtt4b: Or a canvas chair. This might also make a difference

T2.rqselectedalls: affects the gas temperature within balloon after 30 minutes?

A3.withinarea: Within the area of Forces and Motion,

T1.wewillselect: we will select the topic the Speed of Balls at the Bottom of Ramps.
T1.belowarevariables: Below are some variables that might affect the speed of balls at the bottom of ramps.
T1.enumVar3: The Starting Position of the Ball
T1.enumVar4: The Surface Texture of the Ramp
T1.enumUtt4: And the Surface Texture of the Ramp
T1.enumProcess1: We will place a ball on the ramp.
T1.enumProcess2: The ball will roll down the ramp.
T1.enumProcess3: We will measure the balls speed at the bottom of the ramp.
T1.fourcanchange: In this experiment, there are only four things we can change. Any of these might make a difference in the speed of the ball at the bottom of the ramp. These are the four variables you can test in this experiment
T1.enumValue3: The Starting Position of the Ball
T1.enumValue4: The Surface Texture of the Ramp
T1.enumValueUtt1a: The slope of the ramp, which can be not steep
T1.enumValueUtt1b: Or steep, might make a difference
T1.enumValueUtt2a: The color of the ball which can be yellow
T1.enumValueUtt2b: Or pink, might make a difference
T1.enumValueUtt3a: The starting position of the ball, which can be in the middle
T1.enumValueUtt3b: Or at the top, might make a difference
T1.enumValueUtt4a: And the surface texture of the ramp, which can be rough
T1.enumValueUtt4b: Or smooth.  This might also make a difference

T2.wewillselect: we will select the topic the Time for Objects to Sink.
T2.belowarevariables: Below are some variables that might affect the time it takes for objects to sink in water.
T2.enumUtt4: And the density of the Object
T2.enumProcess1: We will place an object into a graduated cylinder filled with water.
T2.enumProcess3: It will sink to the bottom.
T2.enumProcess5: We can measure the time it takes for the object to sink in water.
T2.fourcanchange: In this experiment, there are only four things we can change. Any of these might make a difference in the time it takes for objects to sink in water. These are the four variables you can test in this experiment
T2.enumValueUtt1a: The density of the water, which can be low
T2.enumValueUtt1b: Or high, might make a difference
T2.enumValueUtt2a: The shape of the object which can be a sphere
T2.enumValueUtt2b: Or tier-shaped, might make a difference
T2.enumValueUtt3a: The volume of the object which can be small
T2.enumValueUtt3b: Or large, might make a difference
T2.enumValueUtt4a: And the density of the object which can be high
T2.enumValueUtt4b: Or low.  This might also make a difference

A4.withinarea: Within the area of Plant Reproduction,

T1.wewillselect: we will select the topic Flower Reproduction.
T1.belowarevariables: Below are some variables that might affect the number of seeds produced by flowers in a greenhouse.
T1.enumVar1: The Number of honey bees in the greenhouse
T1.enumVar2: The Amount of sunlight the greenhouse lets in
T1.enumProcess1: We will plant twelve sunflowers in the ground in a greenhouse at the beginning of Spring.
T1.enumProcess3: The flowers will produce seeds then die by the end of the season.
T1.enumProcess4: We can measure the number of seeds produced by the flowers at the end of the season.
T1.fourcanchange: In this experiment, there are only four things we can change. Any of these might make a difference in the number of seeds produced by the flowers at the end of the season. These are the four variables you can test in this experiment
T1.enumValue1: The Number of honey bees in the greenhouse
T1.enumValue2: The Amount of sunlight the greenhouse lets in
T1.enumValueUtt1a: The number of honey bees in the greenhouse, which can be zero
T1.enumValueUtt1b: Or a whole hive, might make a difference
T1.enumValueUtt2a: The amount of sunlight the greenhouse lets in, which can be full sunlight
T1.enumValueUtt2b: Or partial sunlight, might make a difference
T1.enumValueUtt3a: The amount of fertilizer, which can be none
T1.enumValueUtt3b: Or some, might make a difference
T1.enumValueUtt4a: And the type of water, which can be rain water
T1.enumValueUtt4b: Or tap water.   This might also make a difference

RQ1.rqselected: Does the number of honey bees in the greenhouse

T1.rqselectedalls: affects the number of seeds produced by flowers at the end of the season?

T1.DVs: number of seeds produced by the flowers at the end of the season

T2.wewillselect: we will select the topic Algae Reproduction.
T2.belowarevariables: Below are some variables that might affect the amount of algae produced in water.
T2.enumVar2: The Amount of Exposure to Music
T2.enumVar3: The Amount of Carbon Dioxide in the Water

T2.enumUtt4: And the Amount of Direct Sunlight Exposure
T2.enumMat6: A fish tank filled with 16 liters of water
T2.enumProcess1: We will add fifty grams of algae to a fish tank filled with 16 liters of distilled water.
T2.enumProcess3: We can measure the weight of the algae production after one week.
T2.fourcanchange: In this experiment, there are only four things we can change. Any of these might make a difference in the weight of the algae after one week. These are the four variables you can test in this experiment
T2.enumValue2: The Amount of Exposure to Music
T2.enumValue3: The Amount of Carbon Dioxide in the Water
T2.enumValue4: The Amount of Direct Sunlight Exposure
T2.enumValueUtt1a: The temperature of the water, which can be room temperature
T2.enumValueUtt1b: Or a warm, might make a difference
T2.enumValueUtt2a: The amount of exposure to music which can be constant music
T2.enumValueUtt2b: Or no music, might make a difference
T2.enumValueUtt3a: The amount of carbon dioxide, which can be a lot
T2.enumValueUtt3b: Or none, might make a difference
T2.enumValueUtt4a: And the amount of direct sunlight exposure, which can be some
T2.enumValueUtt4b: Or none. This might also make a difference

BOTH.S5aT1a: Here are all of the materials that may be necessary for this experiment
BOTH.track1: In this lesson, we will ask you to set up and evaluate experiments.
BOTH.track8: You will set up (but not run) an experiment on the computer to answer the research question that you have selected.
BOTH.track9: Let's begin by focusing on one area of science
BOTH.S10B1: I'd like to test a different variable for my research question.
BOTH.S10B2: I'd like to pick a different area or topic.
BOTH.S10B3: I'd like to pick a whole different area.

A1.selecttopic: please select a topic by clicking on a picture below.
A1.selecttv: Select the variable you would like to test. This variable is the independent variable of your experiment.
A1.rqselected: The research question you have chosen is
A1.okselected: OK! You have chosen as your Research Question
A1.okselectedText: OK! You have chosen as your Research Question:
A1.cantest: You can test one of these variables in your experiment.
A1.track2: But first you will select a general area for the experiment.
A1.track3: For example, you might select the general area of psychology.
A1.track4: After you select the general area, you will then select a specific topic within that area.
A1.track5: For example, within the general area of psychology, you might select the topic attention to color.
A1.track6: Within that topic, you will select a research question.
A1.track7: For example, within the topic of attention to color, you might select a research question such as does the color of the t-shirt a person is wearing affect attention?
A1.track10: Please tap on the area you wish to use for your experiment design.

A2.selecttopic: Please click the highlighted picture below.
A2.selecttv: We will test the following variable:
A2.selecttv2: , This variable is the independent variable of the experiment. Please click on the highlighted button below
A2.okselected: OK! We have chosen the following Research Question
A2.okselectedText: OK! We have chosen the following Research Question:
A2.cantest: We can test one of these variables in the experiment.
A2.track2: But first we will select a general area for the experiment.
A2.track3: For example, we might select the general area of psychology.
A2.track4: After we select the general area, we will then select a specific topic within that area.
A2.track5: For example, within the general area of psychology, we might select the topic attention to color.
A2.track6: Within that topic, we will select a research question.
A2.track7: For example, within the topic of attention to color, we might select a research question such as does the color of the t-shirt a person is wearing affect attention?

A3.introtitle:
In this lesson, we will ask you to set up and evaluate experiments.

Here is the procedure for one practice trial for this experiment.
A3.okselected: OK! First, design an experiment to answer this research question:
A3.okselectedText: OK! First, design an experiment to answer this research question:

of the T-shirt a person is wearing affect attention?
